newsitem.title: INDIA: Maharashtra tops in India bank deposits, credit.
newsitem.headline: Maharashtra tops in India bank deposits, credit.

text.p: India's richest state of Maharashtra accounted for the lion's share of bank deposits in late December 1996, data released by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) on Wednesday showed.
Six states - Maharashtra, Delhi, Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka and West Bengal - accounted for 67.9 percent of gross bank credit as on the last Friday of December 1996, RBI said.
"Maharashtra alone contributed 20.9 percent of the total deposits and 25.1 percent of the total credit," RBI said.
The growth rate of deposits was the highest in Meghalaya (34.4 percent) followed by Sikkim, Tripura, Nagaland and Himachal Pradesh, RBI said.
The growth rate of bank credit was the highest in Mizoram (21.7 percent) followed by Manipur, Jammu & Kashmir, Meghalaya and Andhra Pradesh, it said.
Nationalised (state-run) banks contributed 55.1 percent of the aggregate deposits while State Bank of India and its associates accounted for another 25.6 percent, it said.
The state-run banks had a 47.5 percent share of total bank credit, while the State Bank of India and its associates accounted for 31.3 percent.
"Other scheduled commercial banks, foreign banks and regional rural banks followed with shares of 9.2 percent, 9.0 percent and 3.0 percent, respectively," it said.
The all-India credit deposit (CD) ratio as on the last Friday of December worked out to 58.2 percent, RBI said.
This ratio was relatively high for State Bank of India and its associates (71.2 percent).
Metropolitan cities had the highest CD ratio of 76.4 percent followed by urban centres (48.3 percent), rural centres (45.4 percent) and semi-urban centres (38.9 percent), RBI said.
